Joakim Ohlrogge wrote:
> We implemented a constraint oriented approach to solve this problem in
> rMock. In my experience it works really well and is much easier than
> try catch. RMock can not yet run in JUnit 4.0 but perhaps this can be
> a source of inspiration:

I've written a JMock runner for JUnit 4.  I'm not ready to release it 
yet, but if someone wanted to swap ideas to do the same for RMock, send 
me a line.

> I have not looked at jUnit 4.0 recently, the only thing I've seen is
> @test(expected=<excecptionClass>)
>
> couldn't that become
>
> @test(expected=<constraint>)
>
> instead?

I've had the same desire.  Unfortunately, only compile-time constants 
(Strings, numbers, arrays, and classes) can be values of Java 5 
annotations.  One possibility would be a String that should match the 
toString of the thrown exception.  But if you're already using RMock for 
other reasons, it seems reasonable to use its functionality for this, too.

    David Saff
